Award.AwardTitle: Connecticut Summer School in Number Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Connecticut Summer School (August 8th - August 12th, 2016) is a program in number theory for advanced undergraduate and beginning graduate students. Events will take place at the University of Connecticut (Storrs, CT). The lectures during the summer school will expose undergraduate and graduate students to important ideas in number theory while, in the evenings, students will work in groups on problem sets and projects, both computational and theoretical in nature. This summer school is designed to prepare the students for research conferences in number theory, in particular the research conference on elliptic curves and modular forms (August 12th - August 14th, 2016) that will follow the summer school.

Funding from the National Science Foundation will make it possible for undergraduate and graduate students to attend the summer school and conference, and provide an opportunity for participants who have no other federal support and participants who are members of groups that are under-represented in the mathematical sciences. The events will introduce undergraduate and graduate students to accessible topics that are fundamental to contemporary number theory, and will bring together faculty and students in a cooperative environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this NSF grant was to fund the Connecticut Summer School in Number Theory, during August 8-12, 2016, at the University of Connecticut, aimed at advanced undergraduate students and beginning graduate students. This was followed by the “Conference on Elliptic Curves, Modular Forms,and Related topics”, during August 12-14, 2016 (separately funded by another NSF grant DMS-1252815). The summer school consisted of five mini-courses on contemporary number theory: (1) Introduction to modular forms, (2) Introduction to elliptic curves, (3) Computational methods for modular and Shimura curves, (4) Introduction to the local-global principle, and (5) Gauss sums and the Weil Conjectures. On each day there was a plenary lecture by a visiting mathematician: “Gauss and the Arithmetic-Geometric Mean” by David Cox, “Mock and Quantum Modular Forms” by Amanda Folsom, “Sphere Packings and Modular Forms” by Stephen D. Miller, “Why is the Riemann Hypothesis important?” by Keith Conrad (replacing Ila Varma who could not attend due to illness). In addition to the lectures, we offered tutorials on Sage, Magma, LaTeX, and Beamer and a panel discussion about graduate school in mathematics.

The summer school was attended by 36 graduate students and 27 undergraduates, coming from a variety of universities and colleges in the US.  We made a special effort to increase the diversity among participants (e.g., the attendants of the summer school were 40% female).

Based on a exit survey conducted after the summer school, all of the respondents said that their overall experience was excellent (48%) or good (52%). Furthermore, over 60% said their level of interest in number theory after CTNT had increased (the rest said it was about the same). Here are some comments left by students in the survey:

  1. “I've attended many summer programs at the undergraduate level, however this is by far my favorite program that specifically piqued my interest in Number Theory. I'm very very thankful for attending this program and inspiring me to continue in Number Theory!!!”

  2. “I was an undergraduate in the summer after my junior year and had never seen elliptic curves or modular forms in a classroom setting. Seeing these things (and the other lectures I attended) was inspiring, but meeting all of the fantastic people that study number theory was so so enjoyable! I loved it - wouldn't change a thing!”

  3. “The best part was the networking. I made many good friends at the summer school.”

  4. “I liked the level the topics were covered. The introduction to modular forms was right at my level. The courses really helped me figure out at least what was being talked about at the conference following the summer school.”

The summer school website (ctnt.math.uconn.edu) has links to lecture notes, exercises, projects and the YouTube playlists of videos of the lectures. All this content is publicly available.
